'''Steve Guyger''' (born September 12, 1952) is an [[United States|American]] [[Chicago blues]] harmonica player, singer, and songwriter. He has recorded five [[album]]s since 1997,<ref name="AMG"/> having previously backed [[Jimmy Rogers]] for almost fifteen years.<ref name="Bluesart"/>

Rick Estrin, from [[Little Charlie & the Nightcats|Rick Estrin & the Nightcats]], referred to Guyger in the liner notes of one of the latter's  albums as "a true master of the blues harmonica."<ref name="Bluesart">{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.bluesart.at/NeueSeiten/Steve%20Guyger+2008.html |title=Steve Guyger: Blue Collar Blues, Part I: Building A Foundation |publisher=Bluesart.at |date= |accessdate=2013-03-20}}</ref> Guyger has played with Rogers, [[Charlie Musselwhite]], [[Little Sammy Davis]] and [[Mark Hummel]], and is proficient in both [[diatonic harmonica|diatonic]] and [[chromatic harmonica|chromatic]] instruments.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bluesfestival.ch/v2/index.php/de/artists/item/steve-guyger?category_id=4 |title=Lucerne Blues Festival 2012 - Steve Guyger |publisher=Bluesfestival.ch |date= |accessdate=2013-03-20}}</ref>

==Biography==
Guyger was born in [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]], United States, and initially studied guitar for five years before his future sister-in-law gave him a harmonica as a gift. Inspired by watching various blues musicians following trips to both [[New York City|New York]] and [[Chicago]], Guyger formed his own band in the late 1970s.  Personnel came and went and he changed the name of the band to the Excellos in 1980, who steadily built up a growing reputation playing in both Philadelphia and New York.<ref name="Bluesart"/> Guyger started backing Jimmy Rogers in 1980, and played with him until just before Rogers' death in 1997.<ref name="stlblues1">{{cite web|url=http://www.stlblues.net/reviews_steveguyger_radioblues.htm |title=STLBlues Reviews - Steve Guyger - Radio Blues |publisher=Stlblues.net |date= |accessdate=2013-03-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1996.html |title=The Dead Rock Stars Club 1996 - 1997 |publisher=Thedeadrockstarsclub.com |date= |accessdate=2013-03-20}}</ref> That same year Guyger's debut album, ''Last Train to Dover'', was released.<ref name="AMG"/>

In 1999, [[Severn Records]] released Guyger's third album, ''Past Life Blues''.<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Bluesmgt">{{cite web|url=http://www.bluesmgtgroup.com/pub/clients/Steve_Guyger/index.html |title=Steve Guyger & The Excellos |publisher=Bluesmgtgroup.com |date= |accessdate=2013-03-20}}</ref>

In 2008, Guyger performed at the Lucerne Blues Festival.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bluesfestival.ch/v2/index.php/de/artists/category/artists-2008 |title=Lucerne Blues Festival 2012 - Artists 2008 |publisher=Bluesfestival.ch |date= |accessdate=2013-03-20}}</ref> His most recent album, ''Radio Blues'' was released in March the same year to critical acclaim.<ref name="stlblues1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.acousticmusic.com/fame/p05813.htm |title=Fame Review: Steve Guyger - Radio Blues |publisher=Acousticmusic.com |date= |accessdate=2013-03-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Henderson |first=Alex |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/radio-blues-mw0000503914 |title=Radio Blues - Steve Guyger : Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date=2008-03-18 |accessdate=2013-03-20}}</ref> His guest musicians included [[Johnny Moeller]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/radio-blues-mw0000503914/credits |title=Radio Blues - Steve Guyger : Credits |publisher=AllMusic |date=2008-03-18 |accessdate=2013-03-20}}</ref> The following year his work saw Guyger nominated for a [[Blues Music Award]].<ref name="Steve">{{cite web|url=http://www.steveguyger.com/ |title=Steve Guyger |publisher=Steveguyger.com |date= |accessdate=2013-03-20}}</ref>

In 2010, he issued an instructional [[DVD]], entitled ''Blues Harmonica'', published by the [[Hal Leonard Corporation]]. He currently endorses [[Hohner]] harmonicas.<ref name="Steve"/>
